Below is a **back‑of‑the‑envelope example** that shows the order‑of‑magnitude difference between a modern 5 G “small‑cell” site and a conventional 4 G macro‑cell site.  
The numbers are illustrative only – real deployments vary with terrain, antenna height, frequency band, and how many cells are clustered together.

---

## 1. Typical coverage radius

| Cell type | Frequency band (typical) | Typical **service radius** (where a handset can maintain a good data link) |
|-----------|--------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **4 G macro‑cell (LTE)** | 700 MHz – 2.6 GHz (often 700 MHz or 1.8 GHz) | **2–5 km** (sometimes up to 10 km in rural areas) |
| **5 G small‑cell (mid‑band, e.g., 3.5 GHz)** | 3.3 – 3.8 GHz | **200–300 m** (≈ 0.2–0.3 km) |
| **5 G small‑cell (mmWave, e.g., 28 GHz)** | 24 – 39 GHz | **70–150 m** (line‑of‑sight only; walls, trees, rain cut the range sharply) |

*Why the difference?*  
Higher frequencies experience larger free‑space path loss and are more easily blocked, so to get the promised multi‑gigabit speeds the network must place many low‑power nodes closer together.

---

## 2. Power that reaches a house next to the antenna

### 2.1. What we need to know

| Parameter | Typical value for a **5 G small‑cell** (mid‑band) | Typical value for a **4 G macro‑cell** |
|-----------|---------------------------------------------------|----------------------------------------|
| **Effective Isotropic Radiated Power (EIRP)** – the power the antenna would have to emit if it radiated equally in all directions to produce the same field strength. | **10 W** (≈ 40 dBm) – many operators run small cells at 5–20 W EIRP depending on site constraints. | **100 W** (≈ 50 dBm) – a common macro‑cell EIRP for a 700 MHz LTE site; some high‑power sites can be 200 W or more. |
| **Antenna height** | 5–10 m (mounted on a pole or rooftop) | 30–60 m (on a tower) |
| **Distance to a nearby house** | 30 m (the house is right next to the pole) | 500 m (typical distance from a house to the nearest macro tower in a suburban area) |

### 2.2. Free‑space power‑density calculation

The **power‑density** \(S\) (W / m²) at distance \(r\) from an isotropic radiator of EIRP \(P_{\text{EIRP}}\) is

\[
S = \frac{P_{\text{EIRP}}}{4\pi r^{2}} .
\]

We then convert to the units most regulators quote: **µW / cm²** (1 W/m² = 100 µW/cm²).

#### 5 G small cell (mid‑band)

*EIRP* = 10 W  
*Distance* = 30 m  

\[
S = \frac{10}{4\pi (30)^{2}} \approx \frac{10}{4\pi \times 900} \approx \frac{10}{11\,310} \approx 8.8\times10^{-4}\,\text{W/m}^{2}
\]

\[
\text{Convert: } 8.8\times10^{-4}\,\text{W/m}^{2} = 88\,\mu\text{W/m}^{2}=0.0088\,\mu\text{W/cm}^{2}.
\]

**Result:** ≈ 0.009 µW / cm² at the house wall directly next to the pole.

## 1. Defining the “downtown block”

| Parameter | Value (typical for a medium‑size U.S. or European city) |
|-----------|--------------------------------------------------------|
| **Block shape** | Roughly square, 200 m × 200 m (≈ 0.04 km²). |
| **Street width** | 20 m on each side (so the “public‑space” inside the block is ≈ 160 m × 160 m). |
| **Building height** | 5–7 storeys (≈ 15–25 m). |
| **Population density** | ~2 000 people per km² → ~80 people living/working inside the block. |

A 200 m × 200 m footprint is a common size for a commercial‑district block in many European cities and for a “city‑grid” block in many U.S. downtowns.

---

## 2. How many small‑cell sites are needed?

### 2.1. Coverage radius we assume

| Band | Typical usable radius (line‑of‑sight, good‑quality service) |
|------|------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Mid‑band 3.5 GHz** | 200 m (≈ 0.2 km) |
| **mmWave 28 GHz** | 80 m (≈ 0.08 km) – strong attenuation by walls & foliage |

Because most operators first roll out **mid‑band** 5 G for city‑wide coverage, we will base the calculation on the 200 m radius. (If an operator wants the ultra‑high‑speed mmWave capacity, they will add many more “pico‑cells” on top of the same mid‑band grid.)

### 2.2. Simple geometric packing

A circle of radius 200 m has an area of  

\[
A_{\text{cell}} = \pi r^{2} \approx 3.14 \times (200)^{2} \approx 125\,600\ \text{m}^{2}.
\]

The block area is  

\[
A_{\text{block}} = 200 \times 200 = 40\,000\ \text{m}^{2}.
\]

If we placed a single cell at the centre of the block, its coverage circle would completely envelop the block (the block fits comfortably inside a 200 m radius). **In the pure‑geometric sense, one cell could technically cover the whole block.**

**But real‑world practice adds a safety margin**:

* Antennas are mounted on the side of a building or a street‑lamp, not in the centre of the open square.  
* Over‑lap is needed to guarantee that users at the edges receive the minimum signal‑to‑noise ratio even when the beam is steered away.  
* Operators typically design a **grid spacing of ~150 m** for mid‑band small cells in dense urban cores (this is the spacing recommended by many 5 G planning guidelines).
